docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, got to have his say Monday on a government-run insurance plan. But now that Mr. Reid has announced he will include a public plan in the health care legislation, he must persuade his entire caucus -- 58 Democrats and two independents -- to unite behind it. The chatter in the hallways of the Capitol on Tuesday indicated that Mr. Reid still has work ahead of him. Some senators are mostly with him but want changes to the legislation. Others are mostly against him.
docs.abstract: Sen majority leader Harry Reid must persuade his entire caucus of 58 Democrats and two independents to unite behind government-run insurance plan now that he has included plan in health care legislation; chatter in hallways of Capitol indicates that Reid has work ahead of him, with some senators mostly with him but wanting changes to legislation, others mostly against him and still others yet to make up their minds (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, got to have his say on a government-run insurance plan at a news conference on Monday. But now that Mr. Reid has announced he will include a public plan in the health care legislation, he must convince his entire caucus - 58 Democrats and two independents - to unite behind it.

headline.main: Voices in Capitol Say Reid Has Some Unifying to Do

docs.abstract: Voices from the Senate corridor make clear Harry Reid has some work to do to reach 60 votes in favor of his form of a public insurance option.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Broadway stage veteran Terri White, who appears in "Finian's Rainbow," which opens on Broadway on Thursday, has lived lyrics of heartbreak more personally than even the most die-hard method actress would want. In the summer of 2008, Ms. White, 61, could not make rent. She was evicted from her apartment of 14 years, after a breakup with a longtime girlfriend. She could not work. She also could not find a way to ask for help. For three months, when she was not crashing on a friend's couch, she slept in Washington Square Park. [NYT]
